children.subject: I'm not sure how useful CS 188 will be, given that I plan to take 189, 127 and probably Stat 140 before I graduate. I've heard that it's really not useful for industry, and on browsing through the content fail to see how it could be pertinent to DS/ML, barring the last couple weeks which delve into the very basics of ML, that will probably be covered in depth in 189. Is there a convincing reason to take 188?

I'm not sure how useful CS 188 will be, given that I plan to take 189, 127 and probably Stat 140 before I graduate. I've heard that it's really not useful for industry, and on browsing through the content fail to see how it could be pertinent to DS/ML, barring the last couple weeks which delve into the very basics of ML, that will probably be covered in depth in 189. Is there a convincing reason to take 188?

I guess I'll just copy my response to the above comments again, if they weren't visible before:

I'm not sure how useful CS 188 will be, given that I plan to take 189, 127 and probably Stat 140 before I graduate. I've heard that it's really not useful for industry, and on browsing through the content fail to see how it could be pertinent to DS/ML, barring the last couple weeks which delve into the very basics of ML, that will probably be covered in depth in 189. Is there a convincing reason to take 188?
188, but 162 and 186 will be rough. Adding another class will be intense.

history.content:
I would recommend either CS168, CS188, or INFO 159.

CS168 is "Introduction to Internet Architecture and Protocols" and is only offered in the Fall. Concepts from the course, such as TCP, are useful for SWE and sometimes come up in interviews. The workload for me was on the lighter side with only 3, 2ish-week long projects over the semester I took it in Fall 2017. I heard they changed it in Fall 2018 to have just 2 longer projects over the semester, but I'm not entirely sure.

CS188 is "Introduction to Artificial Intelligence" and is known to be one of the lighter upper division CS courses. Even though you plan to take 189, it's still a very fun class and offers a bit more coding than the mathematical 189. If you're interested in Artificial Intelligence, I think the course will still be worthwhile.

INFO 159 is "Introduction to Natural Language Processing" offered by the School of Information only in the Fall. When I took it in Fall 2018, it was split into Short Homeworks and Long Homeworks. The SHWs were relatively easy and probably took about a day. The LHWs were a bit more challenging maybe taking a couple days if solely working on it. This class is more coding than mathematical as well. If you're really interested in the AI/ML space, then you might see this class as "fun", rather than "work".

Feel free to stop by CS Peer Advising, with our hours listed here, if you want to speak in person.

_________________________________________________________________________________

Hi Steven Tan, both Info 159 and CS 168 are not offered in the upcoming fall semester.

I would recommend either CS168, CS188, or INFO 159.

This class is more coding than mathematical as well. If you're really interested in the AI/ML space, then you might see this class as "fun", rather than "work".

children.subject: Hey, in regards to a comment in the student answer, no need to be rude about it and say it’s disappointing. Steven is fantastic and the advice can help others in the future, not just for next semester(where yes, it’s not applicable), but more importantly, for all the future semesters in which it’s offered.
unless things changed in the last few days, none of the INFO classes (154, 159) are being offered for Fall.

history.content: I'm currently enrolled in 162 + 186 for the Fall and am looking for a 3rd course that is not an H/SS but counts towards the degree requirements for EECS. If I can only really handle 2 moderately heavy techs a semester, could anyone suggest a third, extremely light course? I would prefer courses that are not like 70/170, and are useful for SWE or DS (besides Data 100, which I'll have taken). Thanks.
history.subject: Looking for a third (light) course
